discussion.content: none of these answers make any sense.

comments.content: True. I would say not tailgating, because Access control vestibule is made to prevent that. But what do to. I cannot guess what they are thinking

discussion.content:
Embarrassing that comptia thinks this is a good question. I mean who in their right mind came up with this question and actually thought A was a reasonable answer?

Mantraps (i'm not calling it an access control vestibule just because comptia is 'woke') BY DESIGN prevents tailgating.

Selected Answer: A
Tailgating in a section that does not have an access control vestibule is the best method to get around an area that has an access control vestibule without being noticed especially if there is multi-factor, or biometric authentication required. If you're tailgating through the access control vestibule, good luck!

Selected Answer: A
A. Tailgating

Tailgating would be the MOST likely attack used to bypass an access control vestibule. An access control vestibule is a physical security measure that requires individuals to go through a controlled space to access a secured area. Tailgating refers to the act of following closely behind someone who has been granted access to the controlled space, in an attempt to gain entry without proper authorization. Tailgating can be done intentionally or unintentionally, but in either case, it allows an unauthorized individual to gain access to the secured area.

Selected Answer: A
A is the only answer that makes sense. Although you would have to be very sneaky to actually pull that off...

questions.question_text: Which of the following would be the MOST likely attack used to bypass an access control vestibule?

A company is considering shifting its business to the cloud. The management team is concerned about the availability of the third-party cloud service. Which of the following should the management team consult to determine the promised availability of the cloud provider?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
D. Service-level agreement

A Service-Level Agreement (SLA) is a contract between a service provider (in this case, the cloud provider) and its customer (the company shifting to the cloud) that defines the expected level of service and the commitments regarding service availability, performance, response times, and other aspects.
SLAs provide clear guidelines on the quality of service that the cloud provider is promising to deliver.
The management team should consult the cloud provider's SLA to understand the guaranteed availability and performance metrics of the cloud services.

Selected Answer: D
As I write this comment, there are 3 out of 3 votes for A... What??? The correct answer is clearly D by the definition of SLA. Nothing else fits.

Selected Answer: D
Service-level Agreement

Selected Answer: D
Service-Level Agreement (SLA)

Selected Answer: D
simple

Selected Answer: D
Service level agreement

questions.question_text:
SIMULATION -
You are tasked with verifying the following requirements are met in order to ensure network security.
Requirements:
✑ Datacenter
- Ensure network is subnetted to allow all devices to communicate properly while minimizing address space usage
- Provide a dedicated server to resolve IP addresses and hostnames correctly and handle port 53 traffic
✑ Building A
- Ensure network is subnetted to allow all devices to communicate properly while minimizing address space usage
- Provide devices to support 5 additional different office users
- Add an additional mobile user
- Replace the Telnet server with a more secure solution
✑ Screened subnet
- Ensure network is subnetted to allow all devices to communicate properly while minimizing address space usage
- Provide a server to handle external 80/443 traffic
- Provide a server to handle port 20/21 traffic

INSTRUCTIONS -
Drag and drop objects onto the appropriate locations. Objects can be used multiple times and not all placeholders need to be filled.
Available objects are located in both the Servers and Devices tabs of the Drag & Drop menu.
If at any time you would like to bring back the initial state of the simulation, please click the Reset All button.
//IMG//

Data Center Port 53 = DNS

Port 20 & 21 = FTP Server

Building A Mobile User = Laptop

comments.content: If you include the switch then it is 11 because there is also the printer that needs an ip address. If it is a mananged switch it gets an IP, otherwise there is no IP for the L2 switch

Each host in the subnet will need an IP address, so SFTP, WAP, Switch, SSH, 5 clients, 1 mobile each need an address. So 10 minimum devs, so this rules out /30 subnet and falls within the limits of /28
you mean Webserver, Mail Server, and FTP server from left to right repectively?

A /29 would be fine for the screened subnet. A /29 will give 2^3-2 = 6 usable hosts and I see that is enough for the screened subnet. But that is not in the option, so /28 is the right answer for screened-subnet

Screened subnet-Answers: 
1. Same analogy. About 4 to 5 devices that require an IP address to be assigned. Network should be then 206.208.134.0/28. Having 14 IPs to assign. More than enough for this use case. Once again... It does not mention scalability. Therefore no need to increase the amount of available hosts. 
2. Here is asking for a server that can handle traffic over port 80/443. Therefore, the Web Server should accomplish this with no effort. I placed the WEB SERVER next to the Front-end Mail Server and just below the switch. 
3. Here is asking for a server that can handle traffic over port 20/21. This should be the FTP Server. I placed the Server next to the WEB SERVER so communication can run smoothly.

discussion.content:
After some time reading my old networking books and asking some other folks. This came to conclusion as for the answers: 

✑ Datacenter-prerequisites
- Ensure network is subnetted to allow all devices to communicate properly while minimizing address space usage
- Provide a dedicated server to resolve IP addresses and hostnames correctly and handle port 53 traffic

Datacenter-Answers: 
1. Here we have a network of about 6 to 7 connected devices. Meaning we need around those IP Addresses to fulfill the requirement solicited. Therefore, long story short, the network of choice should be 192.168.1.0/28. Meaning to have 14 IPs to assign to any device within the network. The instructions do not mention scalabilty. Therefore, this amount of IPs should be just fine by accomplishing its objective.
2. Thiis is pretty straight forward. Port #53 is the default DNS port number. Therefore, answer should be DNS Server.

Can anyone explain why it is /28 subnetting for each? Thanks.

comments.content: Best advice is to look at Professor messer Seven subnetting

The question asks you to choose the subnet while minimizing address space usage.
/28 will give you 16 IPs (14 usable). The lower the subnet number - the more IPs you get; which in this case don't need more. And the higher the number - the fewer IPs, which in this case you only have /30 which gives you only 4 IPs (2 usable).

questions.question_text: A new company recently moved into an empty office space. Within days, users in the next office began noticing increased latency and packet drops with their Wi-Fi-connected devices. Which of the following is the MOST likely reason for this issue?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. A new company moved in. So the resources from the other office is not being used and shouldn't have any congestion. Whether it be WiFi or wired, it shouldn't cause congestion in the network since it's a different company. It doesn't say they're sharing network.

Selected Answer: A
Network congestion would be if they were all on the same network, from the question I’m coming to the conclusion these are two different offices with two different WiFi connections. The new office’s channel is overlapping with the preexisting office, causing them to have issues.

If the answer is channel overlap, wouldn't both companies experience problems? Its not like one channel eats the other, they are the same and conflict with each other unless I'm missing something. The question also forces you to assume infrastructure was added to the equation. Bad question.

Selected Answer: A
Network congestion would affect wired network connections as well, not just Wi-Fi-connected devices. The fact that the users in the next office only experienced increased latency and packet drops with their Wi-Fi-connected devices, and not with wired connections, suggests that the issue is specific to the Wi-Fi network.

Selected Answer: E
Network congestion can manifest in various symptoms, including:

Slow data transfer: Files or data taking longer than usual to upload or download.
Increased latency: Delays in data transmission resulting in higher response times.
Packet loss: Data packets failing to reach their destination due to network congestion, resulting in dropped packets.

Selected Answer: A
It is most likely the new company that moved in has channels set to similar frequencies which will cause overlapping. Network congestion would be an occurrence within a single network's devices.

Selected Answer: A
For Sure!

It is an evil worded question. A new office moved next door, but they are not facing the issue. The issue is faced by the office next door. I did not see that for a long time.
So, it is definitely channel overlap

comments.content:
"increased latency and packet drops with their Wi-Fi-connected devices"
only wifi

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
It never said the new company set up their own wireless network. If it's not in the question, I try not to assume that it will be a part of the answer when it comes to CompTIA.

Selected Answer: A
Since the question specifies that users "with their Wi-Fi connected devices" experience increased latency and packet drops, it indicates about channel overlapping.

comments.content: I totally missed that. Spot on

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
The added people is only thing that changed, so its congestion, E

Selected Answer: E
E. 
Empty office gets filled with new people for using wifi, other office is now experiencing slowdowns.

iSCSI is an acronym that stands for Internet Small Computer System Interface. It is a storage area networking (SAN) protocol used to send block storage from storage arrays or devices to client computers that aren’t directly connected to those devices. iSCSI provides block-level access to storage devices by carrying SCSI commands over a TCP/IP network. iSCSI facilitates data transfers over intranets and to manage storage over long distances.

By process of elimination, it is just C. SFTP, FTP are irrelevant to this, and fiber wouldn't make sense since they're using shielded twisted pair, which is copper, so just C even if you don't know what it is

If the medium for communication is specified as shielded twisted pair (STP), which is indeed a copper cable, and considering the options provided, iSCSI (Internet Small Computer System Interface) would be the more logical choice.

iSCSI is a protocol that allows the transmission of SCSI (Small Computer System Interface) commands and data over IP networks. It is often used in SAN environments to enable block-level storage access over Ethernet networks. Since iSCSI can operate over standard Ethernet infrastructure, including shielded twisted pair cabling, it aligns with the specified medium in the question.

So, the revised and more suitable choice for the company's needs would be:

C. iSCSI

comments.content: Thanks for clarifying guys!

Chatgpt is just a language model. STP here means Shielded Twisted Pair (not Spanning tree protocol). STP is copper and not used in Fiber. FC requires Fiber and the other option for SAN is iSCSI (when FCoE is not in the option)

Ok, but in this case GPT show "STP" as Spanning Tree Protocol, and we know Spanning is a protocol to eliminate switch loop. STP on the question refer as Shielded Twisted pair, so in the case C is correct.

discussion.content:
ChatGPT:

B. Fibre Channel would be the best protocol for a company that is designing a Storage Area Network (SAN) and wants to use Spanning Tree Protocol (STP) as its medium for communication.

Fibre Channel is a high-speed data transfer protocol commonly used in SANs. It is designed specifically for storage traffic and provides a reliable, low-latency transport for block-level data.

STP is a protocol used in Ethernet networks to prevent loops in the network topology. It is important to prevent loops in SANs to avoid data corruption or loss. Using STP with Fibre Channel can help ensure that the SAN network is resilient and reliable.

SFTP (Secure File Transfer Protocol), iSCSI (Internet Small Computer System Interface), and FTP (File Transfer Protocol) are all file transfer protocols that operate over IP networks, and are not typically used as the medium for communication in SANs.
iSCSI is a protocol that enables the transmission of block-level storage data over IP networks, including Ethernet networks. the answer is C

Selected Answer: C
STP = shielded twisted pair, an Ethernet cable sort. iSCSI works via Ethernet, answer is correct.

questions.question_text: A company is designing a SAN and would like to use STP as its medium for communication. Which of the following protocols would BEST suit the company's needs?
